conclusion: Analyze the p-V diagram to determine processes between states A, B, and C using the ideal gas law.
The image depicts a p-V diagram with a vertical process from A to B (constant pressure) and a horizontal process from B to C (constant volume).
From state A to B, pressure is constant at 3 × 10^3 Pa, work done is W = 1 J.
Using the first law of thermodynamics, ΔU = Q - W, with Q = 0, so ΔU = W = 1 J.
For an ideal gas, ΔU = n × C_v × ΔT = n × (3/2)R × ΔT = 1 J.
Solving for ΔT gives ΔT = 2R J/molK. Using R = 8.314 J/molK, ΔT = 16.628 K.
Temperature at state B is T_B = 27°C + 16.628 K = 43.628°C.
From state B to C, volume is constant at 2 × 10^-3 m³, work done is W = -1 J.
Temperature at state C is T_C = T_B - (ΔU / n × C_v) = 43.628°C - 16.628°C = 27°C.
The temperature of the gas at state C is 27°C.
